questions.text: Arrange the following afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle from medial to lateral? General somatic Efferent Special somatic Afferent Special somatic EFferent Special visceral Efferent Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, d, b, c From medial to lateral ,the afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle are general visceral,special visceral,general somatic,special somatic.

Highyeild:

Somatic Afferent (Sensory): Somatic afferent pathways transmit sensory information from receptors in the skin, muscles, tendons, joints, and other external structures to the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord ). This information includes sensations like touch, temperature, pain, and proprioception (sense of body position). Somatic sensory pathways travel along nerves, such as the spinal nerves and cranial nerves, to convey sensory data to the CNS for processing and interpretation. Somatic Efferent (Motor): Somatic efferent pathways transmit motor commands from the central nervous system to the skeletal muscles. These pathways initiate voluntary movements and are under conscious control. The motor commands travel along motor neurons from the CNS to the muscles, enabling actions like walking, running, and lifting objects . Special visceral efferent (SVE) Subset of motor neurons that innervate certain muscles derived from the embryonic pharyngeal arches . These muscles are involved in specialized functions related to feeding and facial expression The cranial nerves associated with SVE include: Cranial Nerve V (Trigeminal Nerve): SVE component controls the muscles of mastication (chewing) derived from the first pharyngeal arch. Cranial Nerve VII (Facial Nerve): SVE component controls muscles of facial expression derived from the second pharyngeal arch. Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve): The SVE component controls the stylopharyngeus muscle, which is associated with swallowing and speech and is derived from the third pharyngeal arch. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): The SVE component controls certain muscles of the palate and pharynx, which are involved in swallowing and vocalization. The vagus nerve also has other functions beyond SVE. ORIGIN AND DERIVATIVE OF BASAL PLATE AND ALAR PLATE Basal Plate Alar Plate Ventral Thickening Dorsal Thickening Give Rise To Motor Nuclei-General Visceral Efferent Nuclei Special Visceral Efferent Of Cranial Nerve C.N 9,10,12 Somatic Efferent Of 12 Give Rise To Sensory Nuclei of cranial nerve 5,7,8,9,10 Inferior Olivary Nucleus Mesencephalic Nucleus Of C.N 5 Forms The Motor Part Of The Spinal Cord(Ventral Cords) Forms The Sensory Part Of The Spinal Cord(Dorsal Horn) The Rhombic Lip Develops Into The Cerebellum And Nuclei

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. General somatic Efferent- The general (spinal) somatic efferent neurons (GSE, somatomotor, or somatic motor fibers), arise from motor neuron cell bodies in the ventral horns of the gray matter within the spinal cord. They exit the spinal cord through the ventral roots, carrying motor impulses to skeletal muscle through a neuromuscular junction. OPTION B. Special somatic Afferen t -Special somatic afferent fibers (SSA) are the afferent nerve fibers that carry information from the special senses of vision, hearing and balance. OPTION D. Special visceral Efferen t- Examples of muscles innervated by special visceral efferent fibers include: Flat skeletal muscles of the face and scalp, the stapedius muscle of the middle ear,the posterior belly of the digastric muscle, and the stylohyoid muscle.

questions.text: Anterior Relations of the third part of duodenum are all except:
questions.correct_answer: A. Fundus of stomach and gallbladder
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fundus of stomach and gallbladder

Highyeild:

The duodenum is a 20-30 cm C-shaped hollow viscus and lies at the level of L1-3 Begins at the duodenal bulb and ends at the ligament of Treitz It is composed of four distinct parts. The first 2.5 cm of the first part of the duodenum is intraperitoneal . Meanwhile, the remaining parts of the duodenum are retroperitoneal . The anterior surface of duodenum is mostly covered by the peritoneum except for second part of the duodenum which is crossed by transverse mesocolon and the third part which is crossed by superior mesenteric vessels Arterial supply Duodenal cap (first 2.5 cm): right gastric artery, right gastroepiploic artery Remaining D1 to midD2: superior pancreaticoduodenal artery (branch of gastroduodenal artery) Mid D2 to ligament of Treitz: inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries (branch of SMA) Venous drainage Duodenal cap (first 2.5 cm): prepyloric vein (drains to portal vein) Remaining duodenum: superior pancreaticoduodenal vein (drains to portal vein) and inferior pancreaticoduodenal vein (drains to superior mesenteric vein) Lymphatic drainage : Pancreaticoduodenal nodes that drain into coeliac nodes and superior mesenteric nodes Innervation Sympathetic via the coeliac plexus and superior mesenteric plexus Parasympathetic via anterior and posterior vagal trunks Relations of the 3rd part of duodenum Superior Anterior Posterior Head of pancreas Jejunal loops Root of mesentery Superior mesenteric vessels Jejunal loops Right ureter Right psoas major Right gonadal vessels Inferior vena cava Abdominal aorta

questions.text: Which of the following is supplied by superior gluteal nerves? Gluteus medius Gluteus minimus Pyriformis Tensor fascia lata Select the correct option from the given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, b and d

Highyeild:

SUPERIOR GLUTEAL NERVE (L4, L5, S1) The superior gluteal nerve is a branch of the lumbosacral plexus. It enters the gluteal region through the greater sciatic foramen, above the piriformis, runs forwards between the gluteus medius and minimus, and supplies three muscles, viz. the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus and the tensor fasciae lata . INFERIOR GLUTEAL NERVE (L5, S1, S2) Inferior gluteal nerve is also a branch of the sacral plexus given off in the pelvis. It enters the gluteal region through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis, and ends by supplying the gluteus maximus only , to which it is fully committed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A : Gluteus medius The gluteus medius, one of the three gluteal muscles, is a broad, thick, radiating muscle. It is situated on the outer surface of the pelvis. Its posterior third is covered by the gluteus maximus, its anterior two-thirds by the gluteal aponeurosis Option C. Piriformis syndrome causes pain or numbness in your butt, hip or upper leg. It occurs when the piriformis muscle presses on the sciatic nerve. The condition may be caused by injury, swelling, muscle spasms or scar tissue in the piriformis. Most episodes go away in a few days or weeks with rest and simple Option D. Tensor fascia lata is a muscle of the thigh. Together with the gluteus maximus, it acts on the iliotibial band and is continuous with the iliotibial tract, which attaches to the tibia.

Extraedge:

Gluteus Medius ● Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines. ● Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. Gluteus Minimus ● Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines ● Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter Gluteus Maximus ● Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament ● Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text: Which of the following statements given below regarding the muscle shown in the image are correct? They Retract the scapula along with middle fibers of trapezius. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of trapezius. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3 are correct statement The muscles marked in the above image are rhomboids minor and major. These muscles cause retraction and elevation of the scapula and they rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly.

Highyeild:

The rhomboid major and minor are a group of deep intrinsic shoulder muscles that, together with the sternocleidomastoid, trapezius, pectoralis muscles, latissimus dorsi, and serratus anterior, form the shoulder girdle MUSCLE NERVE SUPPLY ACTION Trapezius Accessory nerve The descending part draws the scapula superomedially, extends and laterally flexes the head and neck and rotates the head. The transverse part draws scapula medially, Ascending parts draw it inferomedially. Latissinmus dorsi Thoracodorsal Adduction Internal rotation Medial extension of the arm at the glenohumeral joint Levator scapulae Dorsal scapular nerve Lateral flexion of the neck (ipsilateral) Elevation of the scapula Draw scapula superomedially, rotating the glenoid cavity inferiorly Rhomboid major and minor Dorsal scapular nerve Elevation and retraction of the scapula Draw scapula superomedially, rotating the glenoid cavity inferiorly

questions.text: Match the following with their functions? Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A4, B1, C2, D3 Nerve functions A. Mandibular nerve Chewing movement. B. Spinal accessory nerve Shrugging of shoulders. C. Facial nerve Taste sensation of anterior 2/3rd of tongue. D. Glossopharyngeal nerve Touch sensation of posterior 1/3rd of tongue.

Highyeild:

The mandibular nerve (V3) is responsible for chewing movements as it gives motor supply to muscles of mastication. It contains both sensory and motor fibers. Sensory from Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head, Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint,Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior part of tongue Motor to Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masseter and temporalis) Tensor tympani, Anterior belly of digastric, Mylohyoid. Dysfunction of the mandibular nerve can result in various symptoms, such as pain, numbness, or weakness in the innervated regions. Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often caused by irritation of the trigeminal nerve, including its mandibular branch. Dental procedures or conditions, such as impacted wisdom teeth, can sometimes affect the mandibular nerve, leading to discomfort or altered sensation in the jaw and face.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A Mandibular nerve : The mandibular nerve gives rise to several branches that innervate different facial regions, such as the buccal nerve, auriculotemporal nerve, and lingual nerve. The motor component of the mandibular nerve controls the muscles of mastication, which are involved in chewing and biting Option B.Spinal accessory nerve; The spinal accessory nerve provides motor innervation to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and the trapezius muscle. The sternocleidomastoid muscle allows for flexion and rotation of the head . Option C.Facial nerve; The facial nerve controls the muscles responsible for facial expressions, such as raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes, smiling, and frowning.It innervates the muscles of the forehead, eyelids, cheeks, lips, and neck. The facial nerve carries taste sensations from the taste buds located on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. OptionD. Glossopharyngeal nerve The glossopharyngeal nerve provides motor innervation to some muscles involved in swallowing and speech production, particularly the stylopharyngeus muscle. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries sensory information from various regions, including - back of the throat (oropharynx), including sensations of touch, pain, and temperature and Taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue
